Award.AwardTitle: The neural mechanisms of duration on contrast perception in natural vision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The visibility of an object is determined by its contrast against the background. But there is another critical factor in contrast perception that is less well understood: the object's duration. Eye movements, motion of the object in the world, and lighting that changes over time, such as flicker in artificial lighting, all act to vary the amount of time that the object shines photons onto the photoreceptors of the retina. Psychological experiments showed that the apparent contrast, the salience of the object against its background, is highest when an object is presented for ~60-~90 milliseconds and reduced if the object is presented for too short or too long a duration. Dr. Stephen Macknik and his colleagues at the Barrow Neurological Institute will investigate the neural physiological processes underlying these temporal effects by recording electrical activity of single neurons from the visual cortex. This project will provide the empirical data leading to a mechanistic account of how these temporal effects occur. Understanding the neural mechanisms that determine optimal duration of object presentation may allow the discovery of the optimal flickering rate in the artificial lighting. It is possible that temporal dynamics in lighting that is different from what is used in today's flickering lighting can support optimal perception and at the same time save power. That is, if visual lighting is optimized to human perception, less electrical current could be used in lighting devices to achieve the same amount of apparent contrast as in current "unoptimized" artificial lighting dynamics.

To investigate the neural mechanisms associated with optimal stimulus durations, the investigators will record from the ON versus OFF neurons in the primary visual cortex (area V1) that increase and decrease their firing rates in response to light increments and decrements respectively. They will test the hypothesis that the interplay between these two types of neurons will explain the variations in perceived contrast associated with different stimulus durations. To ensure that the findings are applicable to real world scenarios such as lighting in the office and home, the investigators will use not only carefully controlled visual stimuli (Objective 1) but also visual stimuli from natural scenes (Objective 2). Finally, the investigators will determine how higher level cognitive functions, specifically attention, modulates the interactions between both single ON and OFF neurons and populations of ON and OFF neurons (Objective 3). Contrast perception is fundamental to all vision, normal or diseased. Yet the large body of scientific literature has mainly focused on contrast across visual space and little is known about how contrast perception vary with stimulus duration. The current project fills this major knowledge gap by taking the temporal aspect of contrast perception into consideration and suggesting new roles for the well studied ON and OFF neurons.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work reveals the inner workings of the brain's primary visual cortex related to an essential visual perceptual effect that is critically related to brightness perception. The illusion is called the Broca-Sulzer effect. This effect manifests in perception as a change in brightness that occurs when an observer sees the same stimulus with different durations. One might expect that a very short duration stimulus would appear half as dim as the same stimulus presented with twice the duration, and this linear relationship between duration and brightness occurs for stimuli of less than ~100 msec duration. This linear relationship is called Bloch's Law. The PI's lab has shown that Bloch's Law is the initial component of the Broca-Sulzer Effect, which describes the non-linear relationship between the duration and brightness more comprehensively for short and long durations. Specifically, the PI showed that when they accounted for all criterion sources, stimulus durations of greater than 100 msec result in dimmer stimuli. As such, there is a sweet spot for visual perception for stimuli of about 80-120 msec in duration, and this has important implications for lighting design and the power savings that can be won by tuning lighting devices to the temporal dynamics of the human visual system.

This research project reveals the explicit underpinnings in the brain that drive these perceptual effects. The initially increased brightness is related to enhanced spike count in the primary visual cortex. This relationship becomes more complex as the neural response splits into distinct responses related to the onset and termination times. That is, as the stimulus grows in duration—up to about 50 msec in duration—the onset response grows in size, but then—beyond about 50 msec in duration—the onset response no longer changes: the onset response stays the same for any stimulus over 50 msec in duration (no matter how long the duration). This suggests that the remaining changes in brightness must be due to the termination response. The PI previously discovered that termination responses were critical to the visibility of a stimulus, but the critical role for termination responses in brightness was unknown. What makes the critical role of termination responses puzzling is that they occur, by definition, after the stimulus is already extinguished. We thus revealed a significant mystery in that the size of this response correlated with the non-linear perceptual brightness of a stimulus that is no longer present.

Interestingly, we found that the rise and fall of the termination response are not in exact temporal lockstep with perception, suggesting that the combination of timing and the magnitude of the termination response, with respect to the onset response, may reveal a synaptic timing-dependent effect on perceptual gain (this remains to be proven by future experiments). The impact of these results is that they frame the temporal constraints for understanding the neural code of the most fundamental of all visual percepts: visibility and brightness. A broader impact is that it will serve as critical data for creating prosthetic devices to restore vision in the blind.

The study supported 17 conference presentations, 42 journal articles, 2 book chapters, and 7 patent applications that were explicitly acknowledged by the NSF. Several papers were delayed by the 2020 pandemic and are forthcoming in 2021. The lab's scientific outreach to promote cognitive neuroscience served as a major contribution of our broader impact in society supported by NSF funding which conservatively exceeded $50 million in equivalent advertising value. These included 24 feature and column articles published in Scientific American, Scientific American MIND, and American Scientist, 1 book, as well as over 100 blogposts at scientificamerican.com, including specific posts highlighting this work. The funded research has moreover been featured by staff writers at Scientific American and the New York Times.
